China. Graphical abstract XRD, LRS, H2-TPR, and in situ FT-IR techniques were employed to investigate the dispersion, physicochemical behaviors of the Sm2O3 modification for CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. And the catalytic performance for CuO/Sm2O3/γ-Al2O3 catalysts was tested by NO–CO reaction. The results indicated that (1) samarium oxide could be dispersed on the surface of γ-Al2O3 with a dispersion capacity of about 0.625mmol/100m2 and the supported copper oxide could be also dispersed upon the surface of Sm2O3/γ-Al2O3; (2) the reducibility of copper oxide was inhibited by the presence of samarium oxide, which could be influenced by the loading amounts of Sm2O3 upon γ-Al2O3 surface; (3) FT-IR results implied that the presence of samarium oxide species made the copper oxide hard to be reduced by CO while enhanced the NO strongly adsorbed; (4) NO–CO reaction could start to react only when both of them were in adsorbed states and the formation of free-like NO3 − species was recognized as the intermediates of the reaction; (5) the reaction activity was negatively influenced by the introduction of samarium oxide in CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. And a possible reaction pathway was tentatively proposed to discuss the NO–CO reaction based on all of these results. Keywords CuO/γ-Al2O3 Sm2O3 NO–CO reaction Incorporation model 1 Introduction During past decades, the NO x elimination by three-way catalysts (TWS) has been paid great attention, resulting in a tremendous number of studies [1–4]. The commercial catalysts contain rhodium as the active part for the reduction of NO to N2 presented the most efficiency [5]. To find cheaper and more abound metals instead of rhodium, people investigated the intrinsic and extrinsic performance of many metals [6–11]. Wörz et al. [10] revealed distinct size effects in the size range Pdn with n≤30 on small size-selected palladium clusters supported on thin MgO (111) films in NO reduction by CO. Yang et al. [11] studied the NO and CO adsorption over Pd2+-substituted CeO2 and Ce0.75Sn0.25O2 catalysts by DRIFTS, and found the synergistic interaction between ionic Pd and the Ce0.75Sn0.25O2 support, leading to the creation of oxide ion vacancies in this catalysts. And Huang et al. [12] reported the Pt/CeO2-TiO2 exhibited high thermo-catalytic activity, stability for NO–CO reaction, and a strong effect of ultraviolet light on promotion this reaction. However, in addition to Rh, the Pt, Pd, Au metals were still expensive, rare, and difficult to foresee practical application widespread in the future. Due to the inexpensive and abundant advantages, copper based catalysts among the transition metal modified catalysts, have been regarded as one of most the strong candidates that would replace existing economically un-benign precious-metal-containing catalysts [1,13,14]. Copper based catalysts have been extensively investigated during past decades because of their importance in many industrial reactions [1,5,13,14]. Recently the utilization of rare earth in catalysts was attractive [14–18]. Owing to own the excellence capacity of release/storage oxygen and the strong interaction with metal sites, the reducible CeO2 has been introduced into many catalysts [14,15]. Sm2O3 [16] and La2O3 [17] which did not form higher oxide were the most effective in selective promoting CH4 coupling to ethane and ethylene. Wang et al. doped Sm2O3 into CeO2 and found fine CuO supported on samaria-doped ceria (SDC) sample for CO oxidation [15,19]. Parvulescu et al. once concluded unequivocally that samarium modified the exchange of copper with the zeolite and the dispersion and aggregation of copper, which could stabilize Cu+-O-Cu2+ cluster active site for NO decomposition [20,21]. However, the knowledge on the use of Sm2O3 as addition for copper oxide based catalysts was still quite limited [22]. With the context, the samarium oxide as the modification of copper oxide was been considered. The attention of this work focused on monitoring the influence of samarium oxide on the dispersion, reduction and adsorption of the NO/CO molecular over the CuO/γ-Al2O3 sample. The XRD, H2-TPR, LRS, and in-situ FT-IR techniques were employed to investigate the introduction of samarium oxide upon the properties of CuO/γ-Al2O3. From the results, it found that the dispersion, reductive properties and the CO or/and NO adsorbed species of copper oxide on γ-Al2O3 were strongly influenced by samarium oxide. The NO–CO reaction could start to react only when both of them were in adsorbed states, but the reaction activity was negatively influenced by the introduction of samarium oxide in CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. 2 Experiments 2.1 Catalysts preparation γ-Al2O3 was purchased from Fushun Petrochemical Institute in China and calcined at 750°C for 7h before being used as support for preparing catalysts. BET surface area was 126m2 g−1. The Sm2O3/γ-Al2O3 samples were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation of γ-Al2O3 with an aqueous solution of containing the required amount of Sm(NO3)3. The samples were dried at 110°C overnight and subsequently calcined at 500°C in air for 5h. The samples were denoted as ySm/Al, e.g., 0.1Sm/Al represented a sample with samarium oxide loadings of 0.1mmol Sm3+/100m2 γ-Al2O3. CuO-supported catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation of γ-Al2O3 or Sm2O3/γ-Al2O3 with an aqueous solution of containing the required amount of Cu(NO3)2. The samples were dried at 110°C overnight and then calcined at 500°C in air for 5h. The resultant catalysts were denoted as xCu/ySm/Al, e.g., 0.3Cu/0.1Sm/Al corresponding to the catalyst with the copper oxide and samarium oxide loadings of 0.3mmol Cu2+ and 0.1mmol Sm3+/100m2 γ-Al2O3, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Brunauer–Emmet–Teller (BET) surface area was measured by nitrogen adsorption at 77K on a Micrometrics ASAP-2020 adsorption apparatus. XRD patterns were recorded on a Philips X’pert Pro diffractometer using Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation (0.15418nm). The X-ray tube was operated at 40kV and 40mA. Laser Raman spectra (LRS) were recorded by using Renishaw Invia spectrometer. Raman excitation at 514.5nm was provided by Ar+ laser. A laser power of 20mW was applied. H2-temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) was carried out in a quartz U-tube reactor connected to a thermal conduction detector (TCD) with H2-Ar mixture (7.3% H2 by volume) as reductant. 50mg of sample was used for each measurement. Before switched to H2-Ar stream, the sample was pretreated at 100°C in N2 stream for 1h. TPR started at room temperature at a rate of 10°Cmin−1. In situ Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of CO or/and NO adsorbed on catalysts were recorded on a Nicolet 5700 FT-IR spectrometer at a resolution of 4cm−1 (number of scans, 32). In situ FT-IR spectra for CO or/and NO in IR cells (equipped with CaF2 windows) were recorded at various target temperature as background for each test. The samples were mounted in a quarts IR cells and pretreated in N2 stream at 300°C for 1h. After cooling to room temperature, the sample wafers were exposed to a controlled stream of CO-Ar (10% CO by volume) or/and NO-Ar (5% NO by volume) at a rate of 5mLmin−1 for 30min. All the presented spectra were obtained by subtraction of the corresponding background reference. 2.3 Catalytic activity tests In this paper, the activities of the catalysts in NO–CO reaction were measured in a flow micro-reactor with a gas composition of 2.5% NO, 5% CO and 97.5% He by volume at a space velocity of 24,000mLg−1 h−1. 25mg catalyst was used for each measurement. The catalysts were pretreated at 100°C in N2 stream for 1h before being switched to the reaction gas stream. Tail gas was analyzed using gas chromatograph with a TCD. Two columns and thermal conduction detector were used for analyzing the production, column A with Paropak Q for separating N2O and CO2, and column B, packed with 5A and 13X molecule sieve (40–60M) for separating N2, NO, and CO. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD results Fig. 1 a showed the XRD patterns of γ-Al2O3 and ySm/Al samples with varied samarium oxide loading amounts. At the samarium oxide loading amounts lower than 0.8mmol/100m2 γ-Al2O3, only XRD diffraction peaks with 2θ at 32.6°, 37.0°, 45.7°, 67.0° were observed, attributed to γ-Al2O3 support. It indicated that samarium species have been highly dispersed on the surface of γ-Al2O3 support. As the samarium oxide loading amounts increased from 0.8 to 2.5mmol/100m2 γ-Al2O3, additional XRD diffraction peak with 2θ at 28.3° was clearly visible, characteristic of crystalline Sm2O3. In addition, the intensity of the diffraction peak increased with the samarium oxide loadings. To clarify the dispersion behavior of Sm2O3 over γ-Al2O3 support, XRD quantitative analysis was conducted by measuring the ratio of the peak area of crystalline Sm2O3 at 28.3° to that of γ-Al2O3 support at 45.7°, as a function of samarium oxide loading. And the result was displayed in Fig. 1b. The dispersion capacity was equal to the intercept of linear extrapolation to samarium oxide loading axis. The straight line corresponding to the formation of crystalline Sm2O3 did not go through the origin but cut an intercept on the abscissa at a value which was referred to the dispersion capacity of Sm2O3 on γ-Al2O3. Accordingly, the dispersion capacity (DSC) of samarium oxide on γ-Al2O3 was 0.61mmol/100m2 γ-Al2O3. Based on the line of our previous studies [8,23,24], we tentatively discussed the possible interaction model between dispersed Sm2O3 and surface γ-Al2O3. As reported elsewhere, two kinds of surface vacant sites, e.g., octahedral and tetrahedral sites, were on the preferentially exposed (110) plane of γ-Al2O3 [23,25]. And γ-alumina could be assumed to consist of particles formed by one dimensional stacking of C- and D-layers. The exposure possibilities of these two layers were equal, as suggested by Schuit and Gates [26]. And based on the consideration of the incorporation model proposed by Chen et al. [23,27], the dispersion capacity of Sm2O3 on γ-Al2O3 as well as the configuration of the dispersed samarium oxide species were proposed, as shown in Fig. 2 a. For a Sm2O3/γ-Al2O3 sample, the dispersed samarium oxide could be tentatively described as the incorporation of a Sm3+ ion into the surface octahedral vacancy, and then oxygen anions associated with the cation would stay at the top of the occupied site forming capping oxygen, for charge compensation (For r(Sm3+)/r(O2−)=0.6886, Sm3+ should incorporated into the surface octahedral vacancy). Accordingly, the tentative model of dispersed Sm2O3 was schematized as shown in Fig. 2b. Based on the consideration of the incorporation model, at most two Sm3+ ions could be implanted in a unit mesh (the area of each unit mesh was 0.443nm2 based on the radius of the O2− ion being 0.14nm) of the D-layer, and 4/3Sm3+ ions could be incorporated in a unit mesh of the C-layer. After all the usable sites were occupied, the capping oxygen anions formed an epitaxial layer on the top of the γ-Al2O3 surface, as shown in Fig. 2a. Along these lines, the dispersion capacity of samarium oxide on the surface of γ-Al2O3 was estimated to be 0.625mmol Sm3+/100m2 γ-Al2O3. The value 0.61mmol Sm3+/100m2 γ-Al2O3 from XRD quantitative analysis was in good agreement with the predicted value (0.625mmol Sm3+/100m2 γ-Al2O3) using the incorporation model proposed by Chen and Zhang et al. [23,27]. After the modification of γ-Al2O3 by Sm2O3, copper oxide dispersion behavior on Sm/Al support might differ on γ-Al2O3. Fig. 3 gave XRD patterns of xCu/ySm/Al catalysts. For 0.3Cu/Al and 0.6Cu/Al samples, no characteristic peaks of crystalline CuO (2θ =35.5° and 38.7°) were observed, which implied that copper oxide species have been highly dispersed on the surface of γ-Al2O3. For 0.3Cu/ySm/Al samples, no characteristic peaks for CuO were observed, implying that copper oxide species have been existed as well-dispersed phase. For 0.6Cu/ySm/Al, the rather weak peaks of crystalline CuO with 2θ at 35.5° and 38.7° were detected in 0.6Cu/0.1Sm/Al sample. Moreover, as the loading amounts of Sm2O3 increasing to 0.5 and 1.0mmol Sm3+/100m2 γ-Al2O3, peaks of crystalline CuO disappeared. This result indicated that copper oxide species could be highly dispersed in 0.6Cu/0.5Sm/Al and 0.6Cu/1.0Sm/Al samples while both dispersed and crystalline copper oxide species coexisted in 0.6Cu/0.1Sm/Al sample. As reported in literatures [23,27], Cu2+ would occupy the octahedral site upon the γ-Al2O3 and the dispersion capacity was 0.75mmol Cu2+/100m2 γ-Al2O3, when the calcinations temperature was lower than 750°C. For 0.6Cu/0.1Sm/Al catalyst, after the impregnation of Sm2O3 upon γ-Al2O3, there was approximately residual 0.62mmol octahedral site/100m2 γ-Al2O3 for Cu2+. The loading amount of CuO was 0.6mmol Cu2+/100m2 γ-Al2O3, which was near to this value. Just as reported elsewhere, the dispersion capacity of copper oxide on the modified γ-Al2O3 was suppressed at the loading of modifier lower than its dispersion capacity. For example, the dispersion capacities of copper oxide on 0.6MgO/γ-Al2O3 and 0.13TiO2/γ-Al2O3 were 0.15 and 0.58mmol Cu2+/100m2 γ-Al2O3, respectively [28,29]. For above reasons, the faint XRD peaks for crystalline CuO in 0.6Cu/0.1Sm/Al sample were acceptable. For xCu/1.0Sm/Al samples, no characteristic peaks in association with crystalline copper oxide were observed, indicating the copper oxide species have been highly dispersed on the modified 1.0Sm/Al support. After the impregnation of Sm2O3 upon γ-Al2O3, there were no octahedral sites for Cu2+ upon γ-Al2O3. And the copper oxides should be dispersed upon the Sm/Al support in xCu/1.0Sm/Al samples [28–31]. Wan also proposed that the presence of preloaded manganese oxide, irrespective of the loading of manganese oxide, promoted the dispersion of copper oxide in CuO/Mn2O3/γ-Al2O3 catalysts [30]. Then, it inferred that the copper oxide could be dispersed on the surface of Sm2O3 preloaded γ-Al2O3 in 0.3Cu/0.5Sm/Al, 0.3Cu/1.0Sm/Al, 0.6Cu/0.5Sm/Al and 0.6Cu/1.0Sm/Al samples. Meanwhile, the above results also revealed that the dispersion properties of copper oxide on γ-Al2O3 were strongly influenced by the loading amounts of samarium oxide. In conclusion, the samarium oxide species could be dispersed upon the surface of γ-Al2O3 with the disperse capacity around 0.625mmol Sm3+/100m2 γ-Al2O3. And copper oxide species were also dispersed upon the surface of Sm/Al support, which was strongly influenced by the loading amounts of samarium oxide. 3.2 LRS results To confirm the dispersion performance of samarium oxide and copper oxide supported on γ-Al2O3, the Raman spectrum characterization was employed. Fig. 4 presented Raman spectra for various samples. For Sm2O3 sample, it could be found that strong Raman peaks were observed at 346, 424, and 554cm−1 in Fig. 4c. And these peaks should be assigned to the Fg, Ag, and Eg mode of the cubic phase of the Sm2O3, respectively [32,33]. The Peak centered at 1077cm−1 was related to the S6 symmetry and indicated the Raman active crystal-field (CF) excitation in C-type Sm2O3. This excitation was not always forbidden when the ion was located in a site with an inversion center of symmetry [32,34]. For ySm/Al samples shown in Fig. 4a, peaks located at 1077cm−1 were observed and attributed to the Sm2O3 supported on γ-Al2O3. Moreover, it was evident that the intensity of peaks at 1077cm−1 grew stronger as the Sm2O3 loading increasing. No peaks attributed to CuO in 0.3Cu/ySm/Al and 0.6Cu/ySm/Al samples were observed [35]. It indicated that CuO was well dispersed on the support, which was in good agreement with the XRD results. In addition, the intensity of 1077cm−1 decreased in 0.3Cu/ySm/Al and 0.6Cu/ySm/Al samples compared with that of in ySm/Al samples, respectively. And copper oxide were dispersed upon Sm/Al support was the most conceived and reasonable explanation for this LRS phenomenon. In addition to 1077cm−1, the 0.6Cu/1.0Sm/Al sample was predominated by one band at 580cm−1. Compared with 554cm−1 in Sm2O3 sample, it was still attributed to the characteristic vibrations of surface dispersed samarium oxide species [20]. From this Raman shift, it deduced that the chemical surroundings of the Sm3+ altered in this sample. Here, in order to support our hypothesis about the interaction between dispersed samarium oxide and copper oxide upon γ-Al2O3, the LRS and XRD measurements were purposely carried out on 2%CuO/Sm2O3 sample. From the XRD patterns in Fig. 4d, it was visible that no characteristic peaks attributed to CuO appeared and just characteristic peaks of crystalline Sm2O3 were detected. Thus, it could be concluded that copper oxide was well dispersed on the surface of 2%CuO/Sm2O3 sample. Comparing with the Raman spectra of Sm2O3 in Fig. 4c, the Raman peaks of 2%CuO/Sm2O3 sample became weak and broad. Noticeably, the vibration frequency of surface Sm2O3 species (Sm-O bond) shifted from 554 to 584cm−1, when dispersed copper oxide was introduced into the catalysts. This shift was nearly the same as that of in 0.6Cu/1.0Sm/Al sample, which obviously implied the existence of the interaction between surface CuO and Sm2O3 species. Up till now, it was reconfirmed that both CuO and Sm2O3 could be dispersed upon γ-Al2O3, while CuO were also dispersed upon the modified Sm/Al surface. And there should be the existence of the interaction between CuO and Sm2O3 upon the surface of γ-Al2O3. 3.3 H2-TPR results TPR profiles of the samples were presented in Fig. 5 . The temperature range was from 100°C to 450°C because no evident reduction peaks appeared below 100°C. For comparison, the TPR profile of 1.0Sm/Al sample was also presented in Fig. 5a. It was seen that 1.0Sm/Al sample could not be reduced in this temperature range. There was a wide peak of 0.3Cu/Al catalyst that started at 200°C and the central temperature was close to 249°C. After modified by Sm2O3, there was not much movement of the central peak except 0.3Cu/1.0Sm/Al sample, whose reduction peak was around 278°C. Combining with the above results, they were assigned to the reduction of dispersed CuO upon the support [8,36–38]. For 0.6Cu/Al catalyst, a much stronger peak at 224°C was observed, due to the reduction of dispersed CuO. However, the profiles of 0.6Cu/ySm/Al catalysts became a little complicated. Considering the XRD and LRS results, two peaks in 0.6Cu/0.1Sm/Al catalyst are assigned to the reduction of dispersed CuO (222°C) and crystalline CuO (234°C), respectively. For 06Cu/0.5Sm/Al and 0.6Cu/1.0Sm/Al samples, reduction peaks were also due to the reduction of the dispersed CuO species upon the surface of Sm/Al support. Meanwhile, it was a bit difficult to understand the reduction peaks at 278°C, 251°C and 297°C for 0.3Cu/1.0Sm, 06Cu/0.5Sm/Al and 0.6Cu/1.0Sm/Al, respectively. Just from the TPR results, it could be deduced that the introduction of Sm2O3 inhibited the reduction of some CuO species upon the surface of γ-Al2O3. This similar baffle effect was also reported by Jiang et al. [22]. In other words, the mutual interaction suppressed the reduction process of copper oxide in Cu/Sm/Al samples, which could be clearly approved by TPR profile in Fig. 5. In addition, the H2 consumption of the peaks was calculated and listed in Table 1 . From the table, it could be seen that the actual H2 consumption of the peaks in Cu/Sm/Al catalysts was nearly the same as that of in Cu/Al sample. This implied that the reduction peaks were mainly originated from the contribution of copper oxide and samarium oxide did not participate into the reduction. No consensus on the interaction between Sm2O3 and CuO upon γ-Al2O3 have been reached up till now [20,21,39]. And the nature of the interaction between dispersed CuO and Sm2O3 upon surface γ-Al2O3 was still not yet understood. Based on the line of our previous studies, we tentatively discussed the possible interaction model according to incorporation model. Combining with above conclusions, the dispersion of CuO on the Sm2O3 modified γ-Al2O3 surface was schematically shown in Fig. 6 a. Hereby, there were three types of CuO (α, β, γ) upon the modified surface. Here, the β and γ CuO species were adjoining with Sm2O3, and the existing Cu-O-Sm species were acceptable. When CuO and Sm2O3 loading amounts were low, both dispersed CuO and Sm2O3 species were dispersed randomly and incorporate into the surface vacant sites (i.e. α-CuO species). As loading amounts increasing, this mutual interaction between the CuO and Sm2O3 appeared (i.e. β-CuO species). When the loading amounts of Sm2O3 increased to its dispersion capacity, there were no vacant sites upon the bare surface of γ-Al2O3. And the copper oxide had to disperse upon the surface of Sm2O3/γ-Al2O3 (i.e. γ-CuO species). When the crystalline Sm2O3 emerged, some CuO might dispersed its surface or have certain interaction, which could be named δ-CuO species. Thus, the peak in 0.3Cu/0.1Sm/Al sample was contributed by the reduction of α-CuO, the peak in 0.3Cu/0.5Sm/Al sample was caused by the reduction of both α-CuO and β-CuO, while γ-CuO should be taken took the major responsibility for the reduction peak in 0.3Cu/1.0Sm/Al sample. With regard to 0.6Cu/0.5Sm/Al sample, the peaks around 236°C and 251°C were assigned to the reduction of β-CuO and γ-CuO, respectively. For 0.6Cu/1.0Sm/Al sample, peak centered at 238°C should be due to the reduction of γ-CuO. Considering the crystalline Sm2O3 was detected in 0.6Cu/1.0Sm/Al sample, the peak at 297°C was attributed to the reduction of dispersed δ-CuO. Noticeably, the appearance of the samarium oxide inhibited the reduction of the Cu/Sm/Al samples. In summary, the modified Cu/Sm/Al catalysts were much more difficult to be reduced by H2. Copper oxide species could be highly dispersed upon the surface of Sm/Al support, and its reducibility was influenced by the loading amounts of Sm2O3 upon γ-Al2O3 surface. From the incorporation model view, the interaction between dispersed copper oxide and samarium oxide upon γ-Al2O3 surface could be described. And the copper oxide species upon γ-Al2O3 surface should be accordingly divided three types, i.e. α-CuO, β-CuO and γ-CuO. 3.4 CO or/and NO interaction with Cu/Sm/Al catalysts 3.4.1 CO interaction with catalysts Fig. 7 showed the in situ FT-IR spectra of CO interaction with 0.6Cu/Al and 0.6Cu/0.5Sm/Al samples as the temperature increasing from 20°C to 320°C. The spectra were dominated by one band in the region of 2000–2200cm−1. According to the position of this band and also the fact that Cu°-CO and Cu2+-CO were not stable in current temperatures [40,41], this band was reasonable to be ascribed to the adsorption of CO-Cu+. For 0.6Cu/Al sample, this band was around 2114cm−1. As temperature increasing, the intensity of this band firstly increased to a maximum value and then decreased until disappeared. This phenomenon might be caused by two factors. One was the reduction of surface CuO and the other was heat effect on CO adsorption, as reported by the literature [42]. For 0.6Cu/0.5Sm/Al sample the bands (2107cm−1) attributed to the adsorption of CO-Cu+ varied smoothly although the temperature scale. It was considered that either the sample could be gently reduced by CO or the addition of Sm2O3 could restrain the dispersed CuO quickly reduced. Thus, in order to see clearly the evolution of the intensity of the band for Cu+-CO, integration of these bands was done, as shown in Fig. 7c. Obviously, in 0.6Cu/0.5Sm/Al sample, the intensity of this band nearly kept the same value all through the temperature region compared with 0.6Cu/Al sample. Weak Cu+-CO peak indicated that the 0.6Cu/0.5Sm/Al catalyst was difficult to be reduced by CO, which was consistent with above H2-TPR results. 3.4.2 NO interaction with catalysts Fig. 8 displayed the results of NO interaction with catalysts. For 0.6Cu/Al sample, after the introduction of NO, bands at 1298, 1600, 1630, and 1500cm−1 were detected at 20°C (Fig. 8a). According to literatures [43,44], they could be attributed to bridging bidentate nitrate (1298, 1600, and 1630cm−1) and monodentate nitrate (1500cm−1), respectively. Band at ∼1750cm−1 was assigned to the vibration of M-(NO)2. As the temperature increasing above 100°C, bands at 1242 and 1570cm−1 appeared. They should be assigned to chelating nitrite and chelating bidentate nitrate species [9], respectively. In 0.6Cu/0.5Sm/Al sample (Fig. 8b), bridging bidentate nitrate (1300, 1632cm−1) and M-(NO)2 (1751cm−1) were observed at 20°C. Band of chelating bidentate nitrate (1548cm−1) was also detected at 20°C and the intensity of the band was growing much stronger with the temperature increasing. As the bridging bidentate nitrate and M-(NO)2 species disappeared, chelating nitrite at 1267cm−1 emerged with strong intensity, which seemed to be no depended on the temperature. Herein, the results disclosed that the adsorbed species could convert to chelating nitrate/nitrite species to some extent on both samples with the temperature elevating. However, the NO species seemed to be strongly adsorbed in Cu/Sm/Al surface. And the conversion of the adsorbed species might be a little suppressed over Cu/Sm/Al catalysts. 3.4.3 NO and CO co-interaction with catalysts Fig. 9 presented the results of NO–CO co-adsorbed on 0.6Cu/Al and 0.6Cu/0.5Sm/Al samples. After the introduction of CO and NO, pronounced bands at 1200–1600cm−1 appeared at 20°C, which were attributed to NO3 − coordinated species. No bands for CO-Cu+ was observed, indicating that NO molecular preferentially interacted with the catalysts among the mixture atmosphere. Bands for M-(NO)2 at ∼1743cm−1 appeared only below 50°C due to its instability. Bridging bidentate nitrate (1040, 1293, and 1628cm−1) in 0.6Cu/0.5Sm/Al and 0.6Cu/Al samples was detected below 200°C. Signal of chelating bidentate nitrate (∼1518cm−1) could be observed in the whole temperature region upon 0.6Cu/0.5Sm/Al sample, which disappeared at 150°C in 0.6Cu/Al sample. Meanwhile, for 0.6Cu/Al, as the Cu+-CO (2112cm−1) species emerging at 200°C, new bands appeared: (a) a very narrow band centered at 1380cm−1 was due to asymmetric stretching vibrations of free-like NO3 − ions; (b) band at 1456cm−1 was ascribed to surface carbonate species; (c) two bands at 1506 and 1582cm−1 were attributed to monodentate nitrate and chelating bidentate nitrate species [44–46], respectively. In 0.6Cu/0.5Sm/Al sample, with the disappearance of bridging bidentate nitrate at 200°C, bands at 2112, 1382, and 1648cm−1 could be also detected, which were attributed to Cu+-CO, free-like NO3 − species and surface bicarbonate, respectively. It could be also seen that the temperature of Cu+-CO species appearance on 0.6Cu/0.5SmAl sample was higher than that on 0.6Cu/Al sample, indicating the active temperature of Cu+-CO was much higher in 0.6Cu/0.5SmAl sample. And the NO adsorbed rather stronger in Cu/Sm/Al sample than that in Cu/Al sample. 3.5 Activities of Cu/Sm/Al catalysts in NO+CO reaction Fig. 10 showed the NO conversion and NO turn over frequency (TOF) results of the 0.6Cu/ySm/Al catalysts as a function of temperature. As shown in Fig. 10a, all samples exhibited low activity below 250°C. As the temperature increasing, the activity increased quickly. However, this enhancement significantly influenced by the loading mounts of the samarium oxide. The activity of the 0.6Cu/0.1Sm/Al sample showed nearly the same activity with that of 0.6Cu/Al sample, while 0.6Cu/0.5Sm/Al catalyst performed rather low activity for NO–CO reaction. However, the activity of the 0.6Cu/1.0Sm/Al sample slightly increased with that of the 0.6Cu/0.5Sm/Al sample. Moreover, the NO TOF of the 0.6Cu/0.5Sm/Al samples was also far below 0.6Cu/Al sample, especially at 300°C (shown in Fig. 10b). Undoubtedly, this noticeable change possibly originated from their different surface structures. Combining with the above conclusion, the highly dispersed copper oxide was the active species in NO+CO reaction [31]. Accordingly, NO molecular preferentially interacted with the catalysts among the mixture atmosphere. However, the NO–CO started to react only when both of them were in adsorbed states [10,24,47]. Combing with above co-IR results, it could be deduced that the signals of Cu+-CO, free-like NO3 − species and surface carbonate species appeared above 200°C, which was the point of the activity initiated to increasing. And the CO molecular slowly reduced the adsorbed NO species, grabbed the active copper sites, and formed the adsorbed CO species simultaneously as the temperate increasing. Thus, the Cu+-CO, free-like NO3 − species were recognized as the reaction intermediates. In this work, the interaction between Sm2O3 and CuO could deactivate the surface dispersed CuO, and the surface CuO needed much higher temperature to be activated, leading to the active site not released in time to capture CO molecular. In addition, the more strongly adsorbed NOa probably poisoned the surface. Just as Wörz et al. [10] proposed that at low temperature the NO dissociation was rate-limiting, while at high temperature, the CO adsorption was rate-limiting for NO–CO reaction. In Cu/Sm/Al sample, at low temperature the NO adsorbed strongly. Even the temperature up to 320°C, NO adsorbed species could be still detected. At higher temperature, the CO reduced the Cu/Sm/Al surface very slowly, and the adsorbed CO was not enough to react promptly. Thus, the NO–CO reaction was greatly decreased in Cu/Sm/Al. In fact, Cu+ species played a key role in this reaction over the catalysts, while the addition of samarium oxide dramatically influenced this process, resulting rather low activity of the Cu/Sm/Al catalysts in NO–CO reaction. The above results showed that the introduction of Sm2O3 inhibited the catalytic activity of the Cu/Sm/Al sample. This study proposed the possible surface interaction between CuO and Sm2O3 upon γ-Al2O3. However, the detailed process and the optimal application needed to be further investigated in the future work. 4 Conclusions Sm2O3 could be dispersed on γ­-Al2O3 and its modification also influenced the dispersed behavior and reducibility of copper oxide. From the incorporation model view, the interaction between dispersed copper oxide and samarium oxide upon γ-Al2O3 surface could be described. And the copper oxide species upon γ-Al2O3 surface should be accordingly divided into three types, i.e. α-CuO, β-CuO and γ-CuO. The existing mutual interaction could suppress the reducibility of copper oxide, made the copper oxide hard to be reduced by CO and enhanced the NO strongly adsorbed. And this mutual interaction increased the active temperature of Cu+-CO species to some extent. In the end, the introduction of samarium oxide prominently reduced the activity of CuO/Sm2O3/γ-Al2O3 sample in NO removal by CO. A possible reaction pathway was tentatively proposed to discuss the NO–CO reaction based on all of these results. coredata.dc:description: XRD, LRS, H2-TPR, and in situ FT-IR techniques were employed to investigate the dispersion, physicochemical behaviors of the Sm2O3 modification for CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. And the catalytic performance for CuO/Sm2O3/γ-Al2O3 catalysts was tested by NO–CO reaction. The results indicated that (1) samarium oxide could be dispersed on the surface of γ-Al2O3 with a dispersion capacity of about 0.625mmol/100m2 and the supported copper oxide could be also dispersed upon the surface of Sm2O3/γ-Al2O3; (2) the reducibility of copper oxide was inhibited by the presence of samarium oxide, which could be influenced by the loading amounts of Sm2O3 upon γ-Al2O3 surface; (3) FT-IR results implied that the presence of samarium oxide species made the copper oxide hard to be reduced by CO while enhanced the NO strongly adsorbed; (4) NO–CO reaction could start to react only when both of them were in adsorbed states and the formation of free-like NO3 − species was recognized as the intermediates of the reaction; (5) the reaction activity was negatively influenced by the introduction of samarium oxide in CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. And a possible reaction pathway was tentatively proposed to discuss the NO–CO reaction based on all of these results.
coredata.dc:title: Investigation of the physicochemical properties of CuO/Sm2O3/γ-Al2O3 catalysts and their activity for NO removal by CO
